Fig. 1 XPS spectra of Fe 2p (A), Ti 2p (B) and O 1s (C) for iron titanate catalysts with various SO4 2− loadings. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Subtraction FT-IR spectra of sample AS2, AS4 and AS6 with background of AS0. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 NH3-TPD curves (A), CO2-TPD curves (B), pyridine FT-IR spectra (C) and CO2 FT-IR spectra (D) of iron titanate catalysts with various SO4 2− loadings. Pyridine and CO2 FT-IR spectra were collected at 50 and 150 °C, respectively, and the probe molecules were introduced for 15 min and then flushed by Ar for 30 min at the same temperatures. All bare sample were pre-treated in Ar at 400 °C for 1 h. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 In situ DRIFT spectra for DCM adsorption after the treatment with the stream of 1000 ppm DCM in Ar from 100 to 350 °C. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 In situ DRIFT spectra for DCM adsorption over AS0 at 150 °C (A, B) and 300 °C (C, D), before (a) and 5 (b), 10 (c), 15 (d), 20 (e), 25 (f) minutes after a water pulse. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Pyridine FT-IR spectra over AS0 (A), AS4 (B) and CO2 FT-IR spectra over AS0 (C), AS4 (D) with DCM pre-adsorption at different temperatures; green line in (A): Pyridine FT-IR spectra over AS0 with HCl pre-adsorption at 300 °C. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 DCM conversion curves over iron titanate catalysts with various SO4 2− loadings; gas composition: 1000 ppm DCM and 10 % (vol) O2 in N2 balance; GHSV = 30,000 mL g-1 h-1; catalyst amount: 200 mg. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 DCM conversions and MCM/FA concentration on stream over AS0 (A) and AS4 (B) in dry feeding at 240 °C (blue) and 290 °C (red); gas composition: 1000 ppm DCM and 10 % (vol) O2 in He balance; GHSV = 30,000 mL g−1 h−1; catalyst amount: 200 mg. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 DCM conversions and MCM/FA concentration on stream over AS0 (A) and AS4 (B) in wet feeding at 240 °C (blue) and 290 °C (red); gas composition: 1000 ppm DCM, 10 % (vol) O2 and 3% (vol) H2O in He balance; GHSV = 30,000 mL g−1 h−1; catalyst amount: 200 mg. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Pyridine FT-IR (A), methanol FT-IR (B), in situ DRIFT of DCM adsorption (C) and DCM conversion curves (D) of AS2 and model catalyst AS2F. Fig. 10 Scheme 1 Pathway I. Graphical abstract Iron titanate catalysts prepared by sol-gel method and modified by different amounts of SO4 2− were investigated in catalytic oxidation of dichloromethane (DCM). In situ DRIFT spectra revealed three different pathways for DCM decomposition over the serial catalysts, with active sites of hydroxyls, Lewis pairs and Brønsted acid-sulfate sites, respectively, verified by the designed experiments. Specifically, over sulfate-Brønsted sites, DCM decomposed through reaction intermediate of COHCl, which directly converted to CO and HCl. Sulfation of iron titanate significantly promoted the acidity and reaction activity, with great reaction stability provided by sulfate species and reproducible Brønsted acid sites. Keywords Chlorinated compounds Sulfated catalysts Iron titanate Reaction mechanism Catalytic decomposition 1 Introduction Chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs) have been acknowledged as an intractable class of air pollutants due to their chemical stability and severe harm to the environment as well as human beings [1]. Current technologies for processing CVOCs include recycling technology and destruction technology, among which, catalytic combustion has been considered as the most ideal one due to its low cost, less secondary pollution and high efficiency [2,3]. Generally, supported noble metal (such as Pt, Pd and Ru) catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic activity in CVOCs combustion [1,4–6]. However, for noble metals, there are some disadvantages critical and difficult to solve, such as high costs, high sensitivity to chlorine poisoning, sintering at high temperatures, and loss of active ingredients during reaction. While transition metal oxides show great potential as appropriate catalysts for CVOCs oxidation due to cheapness and chemical stability. The variety of transition metals also makes a rich diversity of structure and activity modulation. Currently, V-based catalytic systems like VOx/TiO2 have been widely studied and used in industrial applications while researchers are still committed to finding catalytic systems more efficient and environmental-friendly [1]. As reported, Cr-, Ce-, Co-, Ti-, Mn-, Fe-based catalysts have shown great performance in CVOCs combustion [2,3,7–11]. Meanwhile, the critical roles that acidity and redox properties play in combustion of CVOCs have been understood to some extent. As reported, SO4 2− modified titania and iron oxide have both shown to be great solid superacid catalysts for numbers of reactions: isomerization, esterification, acylation of Friedel–Crafts, olefin oligomerization and catalytic oxidation, etc. [3,12–14]. It is demonstrated that sulfation significantly develops catalytic properties, especially acidity. On the other hand, compared with pure titania and iron oxide, Ti-Fe mixed oxides show much enhanced structural stability, redox performance and acidity [9,15–17], fitting in with the needs of applied catalysts for CVOCs decomposition. Khaleel et al. reported that the Ti-Fe mixed oxide exhibited good activity and stability as the catalyst for oxidative decomposition of chlorobenzene, which was significantly enhanced in catalytic performance in comparison with Fe2O3, TiO2 and TiO2-supported Fe2O3 [9]. With this in mind, in this paper, Ti-Fe mixed oxides modified with different amounts of SO4 2− were prepared and the functional group nature-activity relationship as well as the reaction mechanism of DCM combustion were studied. In addition, the formation mechanism of oxygen vacancies and their essential role in aryl chlorides oxidation would be discussed in another part of our work. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Ti-Fe mixed oxide with Ti/Fe ratio of 7:3 was synthesized by sol-gel method using isopropyl titanate and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O. In a typical experiment, 10.0 g isopropyl titanate was dissolved in 16.2 g isopropanol and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O was separately dissolved in 32.4 g isopropanol. With stirring, the iron nitrate solution was added to the isopropyl titanate solution and a brown transparent gel was obtained afterwards. Then the gel was aged for 5 h and further dried at 110 °C for 12 h. After calcination at 400 °C in air for 4 h, a dark brown powder was obtained, denoted as AS0. In a typical experiment, sulfation of Ti-Fe mixed oxide was conducted by wet impregnation using 2.0, 4.0 and 6.0 mL of 0.5 M (NH4)2SO4 aqueous solution, respectively, over per gram of Ti-Fe mixed hydroxide (without calcination). While stirring, the obtained mixture was evaporated at 100 °C in oil bath and then dried at 110 °C. Calcination at 400 °C in air for 4 h was conducted afterwards and the obtained catalysts were denoted as AS2, AS4 and AS6, respectively, corresponding to the loading of (NH4)2SO4. F modified model catalyst was obtained from AS2 treated by NH4F with hydrothermal treatment, denoted as AS2F. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The characterization of as-synthesized catalysts by XRD, Nitrogen physisorption, HRTEM, ICP-OES, FT-IR, XPS, NH3/CO2-TPD and in situ DRIFT were previously described in our published papers [2,3]. 2.3 Activity measurement In a typical procedure, catalytic combustion tests over the synthesized catalysts were carried out at atmospheric pressure in a continuous flow micro-reactor made of a quartz tube with 4 mm in inner diameter. 200 mg catalyst with 40–60 mesh was loaded in the reactor bed. The feed stream flowed to the reactor at the rate of 100 mL/min, which was metered by a mass flow controller, and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV), of 30,000 mL g−1 h−1. The feed stream was composed of 1000 ppm DCM and 10 % (vol) O2 balanced by N2 or He while DCM was delivered by a syringe pump. The pipeline was electrically heated to ensure complete evaporation of DCM. The reactor temperature was measured and controlled with two thermocouples located at the exit and bed of reactor. The reaction temperature was controlled in range of 100∼400 °C. Meanwhile, CO, CO2, CH2Cl2, CH3Cl, CHCl3, CCl4 and CH2O of the effluent gases were analyzed on-line at a given temperature by two GC equipped with FID. Cl2 was adsorbed by the effluent stream bubbling through a 0.0125 M NaOH solution, and its concentration was then determined by titration method with ferrous ammonium sulfate using N, N-diethyl-p-phenylenediamine as an indicator [18]. The temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) was carried out under the following conditions. The feed composed of 1000 ppm CH2Cl2 and 10 % O2/Ar flowed continuously over 100 mg catalyst at a heating rate of 10 °C/min at 100∼400 °C. CH2Cl2 and various possible products including HCl. Cl2, CO, CO2, CH3Cl, CHCl3, CCl4 and CH2O were analyzed online over a mass spectrometer apparatus (HIDEN QIC-20). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical properties The XRD patterns of the iron titanate catalysts with various sulfate loadings were shown in Fig. S1, indicating amorphous solids after calcination at 400 °C. All of the samples demonstrated almost identical patterns, implying the same crystallization phase identification, which provided the precondition for studying the effects of surface sulfate species. Specifically, there appeared several weak diffraction peaks at 35.9, 41.3 and 54.6°, which matched very well to the known pattern of pseudorutile (Fe2Ti3O9, JCPDS NO. 47-1777) [9]. Otherwise, the broad diffraction peak centered at 25.4° ascribed to reflections from (101) plane of anatase (JCPDS No. 21–1272), which would weaken and broaden after Fe introduced into the anatase lattice, as reported [15], while reflections from the other planes were too weak to be spotted. Thus, the phase composition of the serial catalysts could be considered as a mixture of pseudorutile and Fe doped anatase with low crystallinity. Nitrogen physisorption isotherms and pore size distribution for the samples were shown in Fig. S2 and the corresponding textural parameters were presented in Table 1 . The results demonstrated the large BET surface of Ti-Fe mixed oxide (241 m2/g), which decreased with loading of sulfate, together with the BJH pore volume. This might be caused by the grain aggregation during sintering. According to TEM analyses (Fig. S3A–D), it can be seen that the serial catalysts all crystallized in form of nanocrystallites with diameter of 5∼10 nm, while the nanocrystallites aggregated to larger particle with the sulfate loading, with the average diameter increased from 100 nm (AS0) to 300 nm (AS6), explaining the decrease of surface area. As seen in the HRTEM image of AS0 (Fig. S4A), the interlayer spacing (d) of the nanocrystallites were about 0.346, 0.248 and 0.143 nm, identified as (101) plane of anatase, (001) and (110) plane of pseudorutile (the enlarged hexagonal lattice fringes were shown in Fig. S4B), respectively, in agreement with the results of XRD patterns. 3.2 Surface hydroxyls Generally, it is difficult to determine the non-associated hydroxyls of sulfated catalysts with FT-IR spectra, due to hydrophilia of sulfate species. Therefore, in situ DRIFT with methanol as a probe molecule was conducted, according to the principle of methanol reacting with the surface hydroxyls to from methoxyls and resulting in hydroxyl consumption (negative bands of hydroxyls) [19]. The results were shown in Fig. S5. It can be seen that AS0 exhibited strong hydroxyl signal centered at 3683 cm−1, demonstrating a large amount of Ti−OH on the surface, while the hydroxyl intensity decreased significantly with sulfate loading, accompanied with the bands shifting to lower wavenumbers, implying reduction in content as well as enhancement in acidity of surface hydroxyls with sulfation. This should be caused by consumption of basic hydroxyls by SO4 2− coordination on the surface. 3.3 Chemical states XPS method analyzed the oxidation state of elements composing the samples by binding energy (B.E.), while all peak correlations were referenced to the C1s core level for C-C/C-H components at 284.9 eV. In Fe 2p core level spectra (Fig. 1 A), there were two peaks situated at 711.1 eV and 724.8 eV for AS0, at 711.9 eV and 725.6 eV for all sulfated samples. For Ti2p, as seen in Fig. 1B, the peaks appeared at 458.6 eV and 464.3 eV for AS0, and gradually shifted to higher binding energy with sulfate loading (459.4 eV and 465.1 eV for AS2, 459.5 eV and 465.2 eV for AS2, 459.5 eV and 465.3 eV for AS6). The shifts of binding energy for both Fe2p and Ti2p core level with sulfation resulted from the strong electrophilic effect of sulfate species on the catalyst surface, and the difference between Fe2p and Ti2p in B.E. shifting implied SO4 2− preferentially anchored at the surface Fe sites, while the Ti sites would be anchored gradually by further sulfation. Moreover, for AS0, the binding energy of Ti2p was 0.3 eV lower than that of TiO2 (458.9 eV and 464.7 eV), while the binding energy of Fe2p was about 0.5 eV higher than Fe2O3. This could be explained as the electron transport from Fe3+ to Ti4+, as previously reported [20,21]. For O1s core level spectra (Fig. 1C), there appeared three peaks for all the samples, which were attributed to lattice oxygen (O1), surface oxygen overlapped with oxygen in sulfate species (O2), and oxygen in surface hydroxyls (O3), respectively, from low to high binding energy. The binding energy of O1s core level increased with the loading of sulfate, resulted from strong electrophilic effect of sulfate species as well. In the meantime, the intensity of O2 increased with reduction of O3, implying SO4 2− anchoring on the surface through surface hydroxyls. As a result, there were fewer surface hydroxyls for catalyst with higher sulfate content. The electron transport from Fe3+ to Ti4+ would be further discussed in another part of our work, due to space limitations. 3.4 Characterization of sulfate species To determine the sulfur content in sulfated catalysts, ICP-OES was conducted, as shown in Table 1. As demonstrated, the mass fraction of sulfur in AS2, AS4 and AS6 were 3.2, 5.5 and 7.6 wt%, corresponding to sulfur density of 3.1, 7.5 and 17.2 nm−2 respectively. It has been reported that sulfated TiO2 reached monolayer coverage with S content of 5.6 wt% [22], which is very close to the value of AS4. To extract characteristic information of sulfate species, the subtraction FT-IR spectra of the sulfated catalysts, with carrier signal (AS0) subtracted, were demonstrated in Fig. 2 . The bands at 1045, 1134 cm−1 and 1030, 1108, 1197 cm−1, on AS2, were assigned to unidentate sulfate and bridged bidentate sulfate, respectively [23]. Besides, there appeared bands at 1047, 1166 cm−1 and 1015, 1081, 1102, 1140, 1224 cm−1 on both AS4 and AS6, which were attributed to unidentate sulfate and chelated bidentate sulfate, respectively [23]. For sample AS6, which exceeded monolayer coverage of sulfate, there were additional bands at 1069, 1120 and 1212 cm−1, as the characteristic bands of pyrosulfate. 3.5 Acidic and basic properties 3.5.1 NH3 / CO2 TPD Here, temperature programed desorption (TPD) method was used to measure the acidic and basic properties of the serial catalysts, with the temperature rising to the calcination temperature (400 °C). NH3-TPD profiles of the samples shown in Fig. 3 A were divided into three ranges as weak (100∼200 °C), moderate (200∼300 °C) and strong acid (300∼400 °C). Based on the work curve of peak area vs ammonia content, the acidity of samples was quantified and the results were shown in Table 2 . As presented, the Ti-Fe mixed oxide (AS0) exhibited significantly enhanced acidity (1.69 mmol/g), even higher than SO4 2−/TiO2 and SO4 2−/Fe2O3 (0.42 and 0.04 mmol/g, respectively, as reported in our previous works [3,24]). Moreover, sulfation further enhanced the moderate and strong acidity, and AS4 possessed the largest amount of strong acid as well as total acid by 1.35 and 2.61 mmol/g, respectively. Likewise, CO2-TPD profiles of the samples (Fig. 3B) could be divided into three range as weak (50∼150 °C), moderate (150∼225 °C) and strong base (225∼400 °C). Accordingly, the amount of weak base reduced with the loading of sulfate, while there appeared much more moderate base on AS2, and more strong base on AS4 (especially) as well as AS6, compared to AS0. The results above indicated that sulfate species of chelated bidentate type possessed strongest basic oxygen and introduced strongest acid (among the types of sulfate species on the serial catalysts). Specifically, the strong acid sites mainly originated from chelated bidentate sulfate coordinated with Ti4+ and Fe3+ on the defective sites. 3.5.2 Pyridine / CO2 FT-IR To further identify the surface acidity of the samples, pyridine FT-IR spectra were conducted, as presented in Fig. 3C. The band at about 1450 cm−1 and 1540 cm-1 in pyridine FT-IR spectra were assigned to pyridine adsorption on Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, respectively. Hence, it was seen that Lewis acid reduced with the loading of sulfate, in opposite to the case of Brønsted acid, while there was no Brønsted acid detected on AS0. Here, Brønsted acid might arise form sulfate-H3O+ structure, according to the results of adsorbed bisulfate or sulfate-H3O+ structure on the hematite reported by Eggleston et al. [25]. As known, CO2 could adsorb on basic sites like basic hydroxyls and basic surface oxygen to form bicarbonates and carbonates, respectively, hence used as a probe molecule for basic sites on catalyst surface. As demonstrated in Fig. 3D, there were a series of bands on AS0 after CO2 adsorption. The band at 1626 cm−1 and the bands at 1578, 1565 cm−1, could be assigned to bidentate and unidentate carbonate, respectively, while the bands at 1478, 1466, 1452, 1392 and 1366 cm−1 were assigned to bicarbonate [26,27]. In addition, the splitting of these characteristic bands might be caused by the existence of binary sites on the catalyst surface (Ti and Fe). However, in the spectra of sulfated catalysts, the bands of unidentate carbonate reduced significantly while those of bicarbonate almost disappeared, resulted from consumption of basic sites by sulfation. Meanwhile, the bands of bidentate carbonate shifted to 1640 cm−1, increasing in intensity with the loading of sulfate, and this could be further assigned to bidentate carbonate originating from CO2 adsorption on the basic oxygen of SO4 2-. Besides, the negative band at 1364 cm−1 together with the band at 1250∼1280 cm−1, assigned to OSO and CO2∼SO complex [28], corresponded with the band at 1640 cm−1 in intensity, hence confirming the assignment for this band. To study the reaction mechanism of DCM oxidation over Ti-Fe catalysts, in situ FT-IR spectra of DCM adsorption and oxidation are conducted. 3.6 In situ DRIFT spectra 3.6.1 DCM adsorption The in situ DRIFT spectra of DCM adsorption at different temperatures (100∼350 °C) over Ti-Fe catalysts pre-treated in Ar flow at 400 °C for 1 h, were recorded at 100 °C in Ar Flow, as shown in Fig. 4 . For sample AS0, the bands at 2932, 2834 and 1130∼ cm−1 were assigned to CH3 antisymmetric, symmetric stretching and CO stretching of adsorbed methoxyl, respectively, while bands at 2964, 2885, 1550∼, 1377∼ and 1363∼ cm−1 were assigned to formate. Besides, the negative band at 3680 cm−1 implied that hydroxyls were occupied by DCM molecules. Based on previous studies [3,6,29], DCM molecules adsorbed on surface hydroxyl group and lost one HCl to form CH2ClO(a), which could convert to dioxymethylene. Otherwise, CH2ClO(a) would also lose a molecule of HCl to form CH2O [30], which could readsorb on the catalyst surface and convert into dioxymethylene from a temperature below 30 °C [31]. Thereafter, dioxymethylene could be oxidized to formate and convert via cannizarro-type disproportionation into formate and methoxyl (Pathway I, Scheme 1 ) [32]. Interestingly, as the adsorption temperature increased, these bands in fingerprint region (900∼1800 cm−1) gradually shifted to low wavenumber (red shift). For example, the band at 1555 cm−1 (antisymmetric stretching of COO-) gradually shifted to 1535 cm−1, with the adsorption temperature increasing from 100 °C to 350 °C. It was deduced that formate as well as methoxyl species generated from different active sites as the reaction temperature varies. As a positive center, Lewis acid site would attract the electron cloud and depolarize the carbon-oxygen bond when connecting to the carbon atom of organic adsorbate through an oxygen atom, resulting in red shift in IR spectra, in opposition to the effect of electron withdrawing group on carbon skeleton. In this case, we could assume that Lewis acid-base pairs activated as reactive sites at higher temperatures, with surface hydroxyl participating in the reaction since low temperatures through Pathway I. Here, the Lewis acid-base involved reaction pathway could be proceeded as follows (Pathway II, Scheme 2 ): the DCM molecules adsorbed on Lewis pairs with the positively charged carbon atom on basic oxygen and the negatively charged chloridions on Lewis acid sites. Next, the adsorbed C-Cl bond would easily break, resulting in the formation of CH2ClO(a), and the subsequent steps of CH2ClO(a) converting would be the same as Pathway I. In addition, chloridions would strongly bond to Lewis acid sites after C-Cl bond broke, leading to deactivation of Pathway II. For sulfated catalysts AS2, AS4 and AS6, the in situ DRIFT spectra of DCM adsorption showed serial characteristics: A pair of bands at 1665 and 1701 cm−1 appeared above 250 °C in the both spectra of AS2 and AS4, which shifted to 1672 and 1722 cm−1 with peak broadening on AS6. These bands increased in intensity and relative proportion among the reaction intermediates as the sulfate content increased, which could be assigned to carbonyl and related to the reaction pathway in which sulfate species were involved. On the other hand, the bands at 1225∼1270 and 1406 cm−1 could be assigned to organic sulfate and meanwhile the negative bands at 1338 and 1440 cm−1 indicated OSO and OSO in sulfate species were occupied by reactants. Besides, formate and methoxyl species decreased evidently on the catalysts with higher sulfate content, resulted from the reduction of the corresponding reactive sites and the stronger competition from the sulfate involved pathway after sulfation. According to the Pyridine FT-IR spectra, sulfation of Ti-Fe catalysts introduced Brønsted acid to the catalyst surface. It is likely that Brønsted acid sites together with sulfate species participate in DCM oxidation via a pathway similar to DCM decomposition over Co-zeolite catalysts, with reaction intermediate of COHCl (Pathway III, Scheme 3 ), as reported by B. Ramachandran et al. [33]. To be specific, the DCM molecule could adsorb on a Brønsted acid site with one chloridion, and the positively charged carbon atom would be attracted by the strongly basic oxygen of the adjacent sulfate species. The CH2Cl2H+ carbonium ion then formed the carbenium ion by the abstraction of a molecule of HCl and the latter would be attacked by basic oxygen to form COHCl intermediate, which could directly convert to CO and HCl and therefore explained the CO generation above 150 °C during DCM oxidation. The COHCl intermediate also explained the appearance of CO band in the FT-IR spectra. Furthermore, a band at 3145 cm−1 was observed above 250 °C in catalyst with higher sulfate content (AS4, AS6), within the region of hydrogen bond between Brønsted acid and the reactant. However, hydrogen bond usually presents as a much broader band, so we can assign the band at 3145 cm−1 to M-O-H+-C structure in step 4 of pathway III. 3.6.2 DCM oxidation In oxidizing atmosphere, the in situ DRIFT spectra (Fig. S6) of AS0 showed similar characteristics as in inert atmosphere. In the spectra of sulfated catalysts AS2, AS4 and AS6, the bands of carbonyl and organic sulfate as well as the negative bands of OSO and O SO disappeared after oxygen were introduced, indicating that Pathway III proceeded rapidly in the presence of oxygen and therefore explaining the high activities of sulfated catalysts during DCM oxidation. In addition, in consideration of the instability of COHCl and the observed phenomena, Pathway III should start at a temperature much lower than 250 °C. To verify the three reaction pathways proposed above, several designed experiments were conducted with in situ FT-IR. 3.6.3 DCM adsorption with water addition over AS0 The experiment was carried out with following procedure: At specified temperature, a pulse of water was introduced into the in situ reaction chamber in Ar flow after the reaction balanced was reached between the constant gas flow of 0.1 % DCM in Ar and the catalyst surface. Then the spectra were collected every five minutes. Bare samples were pre-treated in Ar at 400 °C for 1 h. At 150 °C (Fig. 5 A, B), the band intensities of methoxyl (2932, 2834, and 1135 cm−1) and formate (2964, 2885, 1558, 1377 and 1364 cm−1) increased first and then decreased over time and reached maximum 15 min after water addition. In the meantime, the band at 1620 cm−1 along with the broad band within 3000∼3600 cm−1 of adsorbed water had shown similar phenomenon but the maximum was reached earlier at 5 min, while the negative band at 3694 cm−1 of hydroxyl consumption decreased first and increased over time and reached minimum 10 min after water addition. These phenomena implied that additional water first adsorbed and then dissociated into surface hydroxyl (replenish the consumption of hydroxyl), which would be consumed to form methoxyl and formate, eventually. However, at 300 °C (Fig. 5C, D), there appeared to be some contrary situations. Here, the band intensities of methoxyl and formate decreased instead of increasing in first 20 min after water addition although hydroxyl had been replenished meantime. It verified that DCM decomposed over AS0 at low temperature with surface hydroxyls as active sites, while Lewis acid-base pairs activated to be active sites at higher temperatures, which could be blocked by water as known. To prove this, pyridine FT-IR spectra of AS0 pre-treated with 3% (vol) water atmosphere, shown in Fig. S7, presented evident reduction of Lewis acid, as expected. 3.6.4 Pyridine FT-IR over DCM pre-adsorbed catalysts The spectra of pyridine FT-IR over DCM pre-adsorbed catalysts were carried out with following procedure: The catalysts were treated in 0.1 % DCM/Ar flow at specified temperatures until equilibrium and then purged with pure Ar. After DCM adsorption, the chamber was set at 150 °C, the FT-IR spectra of treated samples were collected as background. Next, the sample were treated with pyridine/Ar flow for 15 min and purged with pure Ar for 30 min at 150 °C. After that, the background-subtracted pyridine FT-IR spectra were collected. All bare samples were pre-treated at 400 °C for 1 h in Ar. In the spectra of AS0 (Fig. 6 A), it was seen that the intensity of the band for Lewis acid at 1445 cm−1 remained unchanged after DCM adsorption at 150 °C, indicating that DCM molecule did not occupy the Lewis acid sites or to be more accurate, not bond to the Lewis acid sties chemically at this temperature. However, after the adsorption temperature rose to 250 and 300 °C, Lewis acid sites were evidently consumed, especially at 300 °C. This also gave an evidence for the transformation from pathway I to pathway II. As a supplement, the pyridine FT-IR spectrum of AS0 with 0.2 % HCl pre-adsorbed at 300 °C presented much less consumption of Lewis acid compared to the spectra with DCM pre-adsorbed at the same condition, verifying the decrease of Lewis acid of AS0 at 300 °C mentioned above, was fairly contributed from occupation by DCM. For sulfated catalysts AS4 (Fig. 6B), the band at 1445 cm−1 decreased in intensity since low temperature (150 °C), possibly because sulfation had significantly improved the acid strength (as revealed by NH3-TPD) of Ti-Fe mixed oxide and hence Lewis acid sites activated at lower temperatures compared to AS0. On the other hand, the characteristic band at 1540 cm−1 for Brønsted acid increased in intensity after DCM adsorption. Here, HCl generated from DCM oxidation would re-adsorb on Lewis pairs to form Brønsted acid. Consistent results were also observed on AS2 and AS6 (Fig. S8A, B), except that AS6 with less Lewis pairs lacked in ability of HCl re-adsorption, and, as a result, consumption of Brønsted acid sites at 250 °C could not be covered up (lower in intensity compared to that at 150 °C). It was implied that Brønsted acid is consumed during DCM oxidation over sulfated catalysts via Pathway III. 3.6.5 CO2 FT-IR over DCM pre-adsorbed catalysts The CO2 FT-IR spectra over DCM pre-adsorbed catalysts were conducted by similar procedure as above. CO2 was introduced for 15 min and flushed for 30 min at 50 °C and the spectra were collected at the same temperature. As seen in the spectra of AS0 (Fig. 6C), the bands at 1478, 1466, 1452, 1392 and 1366 cm−1 of bicarbonate significantly decreased after DCM adsorption at 150 °C and disappeared at 250 °C as well as 300 °C, while the band at around 1620 cm−1 and the bands at 1578, 1566 cm−1 of bidentate carbonate and monodentate carbonate, respectively, showed no evident reduction with DCM adsorption until the adsorption temperature rose to 250 and 300 °C. Likewise, this could be interpreted as that surface hydroxyl participate in reaction since low temperatures, while Lewis acid-base pairs would activate at higher temperatures. The spectra of AS4 (Fig. 6D) showed that the bands at 1640 cm−1 of bidentate carbonate on SO4 2- and 1277 cm−1 of CO2∼SO complex decreased in turn after DCM adsorption at 150 °C and 250 °C, indicating sulfate species participated in reaction. Meanwhile, the negative band at 1364 cm−1 resulted from OSO occupied by CO2, gave the same trend, due to less availability of basic oxygen in sulfate species after DCM adsorption. Besides, carbonate originated from basic oxygen of Fe-Ti oxide (monodentate carbonate, 1578 cm−1) decreased since DCM adsorption at 150 °C, unlike AS0, demonstrating Lewis pairs on sulfated catalysts were more active. The spectra of AS2 and AS6 also gave the consistent results, as seen in Fig. S9A, B. 3.7 Catalytic performance of Ti-Fe catalysts 3.7.1 Catalytic activities and products distribution DCM conversions over the serial catalysts as function of temperature were shown in Fig. 7 , with T50 and T90 presented in Table S1. As seen in illustration, sulfation significantly promoted the activity of Ti-Fe catalysts and AS4 exhibited the highest activity with T50 and T90 temperature at 190 °C and 250 °C, respectively. The apparent reaction rates at 200 °C were estimated to be 0.023 (AS0), 0.040 (AS2), 0.087 (AS4) and 0.070 (AS6) μmol min−1 m-2, based on the mol number of transformed reactant per square meter per minute. The reaction products detected during DCM oxidation included MCM, CO2, CO, H2O, HCl and Cl2(not detected below 300 °C). The selectivity of carbon and chlorine were shown in Fig. S10A, B. For carbon conversion, MCM was formed in the temperature region between 175 °C and 350 °C, decreasing with the sulfate loading, while CO and CO2 were invariably detected during DCM oxidation and carbon balance was reached based on quantitative accumulation of MCM, CO as well as CO2. Specifically, the selectivity to CO2 between CO and CO2 for sulfated catalysts (Fig. S10A, insert), dramatically decreased after reaction temperature reached about 150 °C, while the damping was positively correlated with the sulfate loading. Moreover, the CO and CO2 curves in TPSR (Fig. S11) demonstrated the consistent results that CO curves of sulfated catalysts humped evidently within 175 °C and 350 °C and this phenomenon became more remarkable as the content of sulfate increased. Based on the discussion above, the emergence of CO for the sulfated catalysts was considered to be originated from decomposition of COHCl intermediate from Pathway III. On the other hand, chlorine balance during DCM oxidation was reached through the products of MCM, HCl and Cl2, while Cl2 was produced through Deacon Reaction above 300 °C (Fig. S10). Since Brønsted acid favored the formation of HCl, the selectivity to Cl2 decreased with the sulfate loading (higher proportion of Brønsted acid). 3.7.2 The effect of water addition With addition of 3% (vol) water, seen in Fig. S12, there was no significant difference in DCM conversion over AS0 below 200 °C, but a large declination at higher temperature. Based on the results described above, water addition would promote hydrolysis and inhibit DCM adsorption on Lewis pairs by replenishing hydroxyls and blocking Lewis acid sites, respectively. Hence, DCM conversions remained stable at low temperatures despite that DCM adsorption on hydroxyls still suffered competition from water molecules. However, the conversions decreased evidently over 200 °C where Pathway II turned to be the main reaction. For catalysts highly sulfated (AS4, AS6), the influence of wed feeding mainly lied in region of low temperature, and gradually weakened as temperature increased. This implied that sulfated species together with Brønsted acid sites were influenced much less than Lewis pairs, especially at higher temperatures over 250 °C. 3.7.3 Catalytic stabilities The catalytic stabilities of the samples at 190, 240 and 290 °C, within 1200 min, were shown in Fig. S13. It should be noticed that there was a deactivation stage (accompanied by reduction of MCM) for AS0 at 290 °C, for AS2, AS4 and AS6, at 240 °C as well as 290 °C. This can be interpreted as deactivation of Pathway II resulted from Lewis acid sites attached to chloridions. Besides, the fact that deactivation stage of AS0 occured at higher temperatures compared to sulfated catalysts, was consistent with the results in Sections 3.6.4 and 3.6.5 that Lewis pairs activated at lower temperatures for sulfated catalysts. To be more specific, the reduction of DCM conversion and the period length of deactivation were diminished with the SO4 2− loading, corresponding to the amount of Lewis pairs on the catalyst surface. After the deactivation period at 290 °C, AS2, AS4, AS6 reached stability with DCM conversion of 77 %, 90 % and 85 %, respectively, all higher than that for AS0 (50 %). The stable activities of sulfated catalysts (the data of SO4 2−/TiO2 and SO4 2−/Fe2O3 come from our published works [3,24]) at 290 °C were mostly contributed from Pathway III and hence exhibited a positive correlation with the amount of strong acid (Fig. S14). Besides, it seemed that sulfate species of chelating bidentate type presented the strongest acidity as well as the highest oxidation activity to DCM, as we mentioned in previous work [3]. On the other hand, all of the DCM conversion for the samples at 190 °C remained constant, corresponding to the catalytic cycle of Pathway I. 3.7.4 Pyridine and methanol FT-IR after deactivation After the deactivation period at 290 °C in the catalytic stability test, the used catalysts (AS0, AS4) were tested with pyridine and methanol FT-IR to determine the change of Lewis acids and hydroxyls, shown in Fig. S15. It was evident that Lewis acid sites (1445 cm−1) had nearly been exhausted for both AS0 and AS4. However, the hydroxyl intensities of AS0 and AS4 remained stable. Therefore, it was verified that the observed deactivation of catalysts was caused by exhaustion of Lewis acids (Lewis pairs) instead of hydroxyls. 3.7.5 Catalytic stabilities under wet feeding and inert feeding As shown in Fig. 8 A, the oxygen was cut off after the catalytic stability test for 1200 min (discussed in Section 3.7.3), in dry feeding at 240 °C and 290 °C. After that, the DCM conversion over AS0 at 240 °C remained nearly steady (38 %) for about 600 min as a “plateau”, and subsequently, kept decreasing slowly for nearly 600 min until inactivation. At 290 °C, the phenomenon was similar, with the “plateau” at 41 %, except that the DCM conversion dropped sharply for about 10 percent right after the oxygen was cut off, which could be interpreted as Pathway II being shut down. Meanwhile, formaldehyde was detected as a reaction product in inert feeding, indicating that DCM converted to formaldehyde via Pathway I until exhaustion of hydroxyls. As for AS4 (Fig. 8B), a larger drop of DCM conversion presented after absence of oxygen at 290 °C as well as 240 °C, mostly resulted from Pathway III ceasing in absence of oxygen. Then the DCM conversion underwent a “plateau” at about 32 % and 21 % for approximately 400 min at 290 °C and 240 °C, respectively. After that, the catalyst lost activity quickly till complete inactivation in less than 350 min. Likewise, formaldehyde was detected as reaction product in inert feeding over AS4. The fact that catalyst AS4 deactivated faster than AS0 in inert feeding could be interpreted as its less richness of surface hydroxyls (as a reactant in inert feeding) compared to AS0. With the same procedures, in wet feeding containing 3% (vol) water, the results for AS0 and AS4 were shown in Fig. 9 A, B, respectively. At first, the deactivation periods of AS0 and AS4 seemed to be diminished in both extent and duration, resulted from the inhibition of Pathway II in wet feeding, as mentioned above. Moreover, the stable conversion on AS4 after the deactivation period at 240 °C (29.4 %) was much lower than that in dry feeding (46.9 %), while close conversions after the deactivation period were observed at 290 °C in wet and dry feeding, indicating sulfate species would be evidently blocked by water only at low temperatures, corresponding to the results in Section 3.7.2. After oxygen was cut off, the DCM conversion of AS0 at 240 °C remained completely unaffected (36 %) and that of AS4 reached stability (23 %) after a slight decrease. At the higher temperature of 290 °C, the activity of AS0 and AS4 underwent a slight drop and a sharp drop after absence of oxygen, respectively, similar to the case in dry feeding and stable activities at 44 % and 33 % were reached afterwards, respectively, which were contributed from the continuous hydrolysis reaction. In the meantime, the stable output of formaldehyde could be observed, as expected. 3.7.6 Model catalyst AS2F With F modifying, the crystalline structure of sample AS2F remained almost unchanged from that of AS2, as implied by XRD and low temperature N2 physisorption (Figs. S1, S2 and Table 1), while Lewis acid and hydroxyls could be hardly observed on AS2F by pyridine and methanol FT-IR (Fig. 10 A, B), respectively, indicating the Lewis acid sites were occupied and surface hydroxyls were substituted by F−. On the other hand, sulfate species as well as Brønsted acid on AS2F were well preserved, confirmed by ICP-OES (Table 1) and pyridine FT-IR (Fig. 10A). The acidity of AS2F determined by NH3-TPD was shown in Table 2, with 0.03, 0.94 and 1.00 mmol/g of weak, moderate and strong acidity, respectively. The strong acidity contributed from sulfate species was rather close to that of AS2, while most of the weak acidity and part of the moderate acidity were removed after modified by F−, resulted from occupation of Lewis acid sites and surface hydroxyls by F− as well. In view of this, it was expected that Pathway III would be the only reaction path during DCM oxidation over AS2F. In the in situ DRIFT spectra of DCM adsorption over AS2F (Fig. 10C), only bands at 1726, 1679 cm-1 of COHCl intermediate and the negative band of occupied SO bonds accompanied with the band of organic sulfate were observed. In activity test for DCM oxidation, seen in Fig. 10D, AS2F exhibited comparable activity to AS2 in region of 250∼300 °C while it was almost inactive below 200 °C. These results matched well with our expectation for Pathway III and thus proved the reaction mechanism proposed above. Likewise, the model catalyst could be used in mechanism study of other reactions with sulfate species involved. 4 Conclusion Iron titanate catalysts were prepared by sol-gel method and modified by various amount of SO4 2−. Sulfation significantly promoted the acidity of Fe-Ti mixed oxide without altering the crystalline phase. The activities of the serial catalysts for DCM oxidation were positively related to the strong acidity, which was mostly attributed from sulfate species of chelated bidentate type, and sample AS4 exhibited highest activity with apparent reaction rate of 0.087 μmol min-1 m-2 at 200 °C. Furthermore, the reaction mechanism was studied and expressed as follows: At low temperature (below 200 °C), Pathway I with active sites of hydroxyls, occurred as the main reaction. At higher temperatures, Lewis pairs (Pathway II) and sulfate-Brønsted sites (Pathway III) turned to be the main reaction sites, respectively for unsulfated and sulfated catalysts. The sulfate-Brønsted sites involved pathway proceeded successively through organic sulfate and COHCl intermediates. The Lewis pairs would rapidly deactivate due to Cl poisoning while sulfate-Brønsted sites could provide persistent activity with regeneration of Brønsted acid during reaction. coredata.dc:description: Iron titanate catalysts prepared by sol-gel method and modified by different amounts of SO4 2− were investigated in catalytic oxidation of dichloromethane (DCM). In situ DRIFT spectra revealed three different pathways for DCM decomposition over the serial catalysts, with active sites of hydroxyls, Lewis pairs and Brønsted acid-sulfate sites, respectively, verified by the designed experiments. Specifically, over sulfate-Brønsted sites, DCM decomposed through reaction intermediate of COHCl, which directly converted to CO and HCl. Sulfation of iron titanate significantly promoted the acidity and reaction activity, with great reaction stability provided by sulfate species and reproducible Brønsted acid sites.
coredata.dc:title: Oxidative decomposition of dichloromethane over sulfated iron titanate catalysts: Catalytic performance and reaction mechanism
